General Appearance Evaluation.purpose: Assessing for lethargy, pallor, and signs of dehydration.

findings.content: Patient appears lethargic but responsive; conjunctival pallor noted.

General Appearance Evaluation.interpretation: Lethargy and pallor suggest possible anemia, possibly from hemolytic processes associated with malaria.

Vitals Check.purpose: Monitoring vital signs to identify any abnormal parameters.
Vitals Check.interpretation: Febrile state with tachycardia may indicate ongoing infection.

Skin Examination.purpose: Checking for pallor, jaundice, or petechiae.

findings.content: Pallor observed on conjunctival examination; no jaundice or petechiae noted.

Skin Examination.interpretation: Pallor indicates possible anemia, consistent with malaria.

findings.content: Mild splenomegaly noted on palpation; no hepatomegaly or tenderness.

Abdominal Examination.interpretation: Mild splenomegaly is common in malaria due to splenic enlargement from hemolysis.

Neurological Examination.purpose: Screening for altered mental status or signs of cerebral malaria.

findings.content: Patient alert and oriented; no focal neurological deficits.

Neurological Examination.interpretation: No neurological involvement at this stage; supports uncomplicated malaria.

Respiratory Examination.purpose: Checking for signs of respiratory distress or crackles.

findings.content: No signs of respiratory distress or abnormal lung sounds.

Respiratory Examination.interpretation: Respiratory status remains stable, no signs of pneumonia.

findings.content: Tachycardic rate noted; no murmurs detected.

Cardiovascular Examination.interpretation: Tachycardia may reflect the febrile state or physiological response to infection.

Lymph Node Examination.interpretation: Absence of lymphadenopathy helps narrow differential diagnoses.

Ophthalmologic Examination.purpose: Inspecting for conjunctival pallor or malarial retinopathy.

findings.content: Conjunctival pallor noted; no malarial retinopathy.

Ophthalmologic Examination.interpretation: Conjunctival pallor suggests anemia; malarial retinopathy not observed.

Musculoskeletal Examination.purpose: Assessing for muscle tenderness or joint swelling.

findings.content: No muscle tenderness or joint swelling.

Musculoskeletal Examination.interpretation: Absence of musculoskeletal involvement aligns with uncomplicated malaria.

Blood Smear (Thick and Thin).purpose: For confirmation of malaria diagnosis and speciation.

content.content: Presence of *Plasmodium falciparum* trophozoites and gametocytes noted.

content.altText: Image for Blood Smear (Thick and Thin)
content.caption: Laboratory test image for Blood Smear (Thick and Thin)

Blood Smear (Thick and Thin).interpretation: Confirmatory evidence of malaria from blood smear showing *P. falciparum*.

Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT).purpose: To detect malaria antigens (if microscopy is not immediately available).
Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT).interpretation: Confirms presence of malaria antigens consistent with *P. falciparum* infection.

Complete Blood Count (CBC).purpose: To evaluate anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocyte abnormalities.
Complete Blood Count (CBC).interpretation: Anemia and thrombocytopenia suggest malaria-related hemolysis.

Liver Function Tests (LFTs).purpose: To assess bilirubin levels and liver enzymes.
Liver Function Tests (LFTs).interpretation: Elevated bilirubin indicates hemolysis likely secondary to malaria.

Renal Function Tests.purpose: To monitor blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels.
Renal Function Tests.interpretation: Renal function is normal, no acute renal injury seen.

Blood Glucose.purpose: To detect hypoglycemia, a common complication in severe malaria.
Blood Glucose.interpretation: Normal glucose levels, no evidence of hypoglycemia.

Arterial Blood Gas (ABG).purpose: To check for metabolic acidosis, often seen in severe cases.

Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR).purpose: To evaluate the degree of inflammation.
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR).interpretation: Elevated ESR indicates an inflammatory process, consistent with malaria.

Coagulation Profile.interpretation: Coagulation parameters are normal; no evidence of DIC.

Blood Culture.purpose: To rule out concomitant bacterial infections such as septicemia.
Blood Culture.interpretation: No evidence of bacterial infection; supports malaria diagnosis.

Urinalysis.purpose: To check for hemoglobinuria or proteinuria.

results.content: Urinalysis shows no hemoglobinuria or proteinuria.

Urinalysis.interpretation: No renal involvement from malaria indicated by urinalysis results.

Serology Tests for Differential Diagnose.purpose: To rule out dengue or leptospirosis if needed.

results.content: Serology negative for dengue and leptospirosis.

Serology Tests for Differential Diagnose.interpretation: Negative results help narrow the differential diagnosis to malaria.
